docs.lead_paragraph: Snohomish County electricity users got a hard-won break Wednesday when a federal agency excused their utility from paying over $120 million in contract penalties to the bankrupt energy giant Enron.
docs.abstract: Snohomish County electricity users got a hard-won break Wednesday when a federal agency excused their utility from paying over $120 million in contract penalties to the bankrupt energy giant Enron. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission determined that the Snohomish County Public Utility District need not pay termination fees on a contract it broke with Enron, [...]

docs.snippet: Trying to make up for $220 million lost in a murky deal with the Enron Corporation, the Connecticut state trash authority voted yesterday to raise its rates, effectively increasing household garbage fees in 70 towns -- representing more than a thi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Trying to make up for $220 million lost in a murky deal with the Enron Corporation, the Connecticut state trash authority voted yesterday to raise its rates, effectively increasing household garbage fees in 70 towns -- representing more than a third of the state -- by nearly $50 a year. Though the State Legislature may challenge the fees, they represent perhaps the most concrete example of how Enron's collapse has jolted the finances of people who never worked for, held shares in, or knew the first thing about the company. The deal with Enron, meanwhile, has set off an election-year political fight in Connecticut.

byline.original: By PAUL ZIELBAUER with MICHAEL BRICK

docs.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission cleared the Enron Corporation's acquisition of the Tenneco Natural Gas Liquids Corporation from Tenneco Inc.   The F.T.C. granted early clearance on Thursday for the required waiting period under antitrust laws, the ag...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission cleared the Enron Corporation's acquisition of the Tenneco Natural Gas Liquids Corporation from Tenneco Inc. The F.T.C. granted early clearance on Thursday for the required waiting period under antitrust laws, the agency said. Under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act, companies that plan to acquire assets of $15 million or more or at least a 15 percent stake in another company's securities must get approval from the F.T.C. "We are attempting to close before year-end," said Diane Bazelides, an Enron spokeswoman. Tenneco agreed last month to sell its natural gas liquids unit and the Tenneco Methanol Company to Enron as part of Tenneco's $2 billion restructuring plan.

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation said today that it would halt work at its canceled $2.8 billion power project in the Indian state of Maharashtra.   The decision was made at Enron's headquarters here after the Maharashtra State Electricity Board delivered a ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation said today that it would halt work at its canceled $2.8 billion power project in the Indian state of Maharashtra. The decision was made at Enron's headquarters here after the Maharashtra State Electricity Board delivered a three-line letter to Enron's Dabhol Power Company on behalf of the regional government ordering a stop to work.

docs.snippet: The British bank Barclays has been reinstated as a defendant in an Enron investor fraud suit by a judge who gave shareholders another chance to describe the bank's role in the company's collapse. Judge Melinda Harmon of Federal District Court in H...
docs.lead_paragraph: The British bank Barclays has been reinstated as a defendant in an Enron investor fraud suit by a judge who gave shareholders another chance to describe the bank's role in the company's collapse. Judge Melinda Harmon of Federal District Court in Houston said yesterday that she put the bank back into the case because the law governing bank liability in securities-fraud cases changed after investors' lawyers made their original arguments about Barclays' Enron-related activities. The judge said she wanted to give shareholders another chance to persuade her to keep the bank in the case.

docs.snippet: THE fraud that time forgot is finally going to trial.    Tomorrow in Federal District Court in Hartford, opening arguments are scheduled to begin in the case against Walter A. Forbes, former chairman of the Cendant Corporation, and E.Kirk Shelton,...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE fraud that time forgot is finally going to trial. Tomorrow in Federal District Court in Hartford, opening arguments are scheduled to begin in the case against Walter A. Forbes, former chairman of the Cendant Corporation, and E.Kirk Shelton, former vice chairman. The government has accused the two men of orchestrating a titanic accounting and securities fraud that misled investors over a decade beginning in the late 1980's. The trial will open more than six years after the problems at Cendant came to light.
docs.abstract: Trial of former Cendant Corp chairman Walter A Forbes and vice chairman E Kirk Shelton is set to begin over six years after problems at Cendant came to light; two are charged with orchestrating massive accounting and securities fraud that misled investors over decade beginning in late 1980's; scandal ranks among world's costliest, with stock and convertible bond investors having lost over $14 billion on day after company disclosed evidence of accounting irregularities; photos (M)

docs.snippet: A federal appeals court on Tuesday overturned several convictions against four former Merrill Lynch executives found guilty of helping engineer Enron's sale of mobile power plants to the brokerage in 1999 to help the energy trader appear to have m...
docs.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Tuesday overturned several convictions against four former Merrill Lynch executives found guilty of helping engineer Enron's sale of mobile power plants to the brokerage in 1999 to help the energy trader appear to have met earnings targets. The three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit found fault with the government's theory of wire-fraud and conspiracy that led to the convictions of James A. Brown, William R. Fuhs, Daniel H. Bayly and Robert S. Furst. Those convictions were overturned.
docs.abstract: Three-judge US Court of Appeals overturns several convictions against former Merrill Lynch executives James Brown, William Fuhs, Daniel Bayly and Robert Furst, found guilty of helping engineer Enron's sale of mobile power plants to brokerage in 1999 to help Enron appear to have met earnings targets; upholds Brown's perjury and obstruction of justice convictions (M)
